Answer: This is Earth OKThis is the solar system in which Earth resides. We are surrounded by several other planets and orbit a star we call the sun.Further out in space, there are several solar systems surrounding ours forming what we call the Solar Interstellar Neighborhood. Each of these solar systems contains stars and planets.See that tiny, tiny dot? So tiny you can’t even see it? That is our Solar Interstellar System. From here, we can’t even make out our solar system let alone individual planets. The galaxy is enormous. We are rotating what is believed to be a black hole. Current scientific estThis is Earth OKThis is the solar system in which Earth resides. We are surrounded by several other planets and orbit a star we call the sun.Further out in space, there are several solar systems surrounding ours forming what we call the Solar Interstellar Neighborhood. Each of these solar systems contains stars and planets.See that tiny, tiny dot? So tiny you can’t even see it? That is our Solar Interstellar System. From here, we can’t even make out our solar system let alone individual planets. The galaxy is enormous. We are rotating what is believed to be a black hole. Current scientific estimates conclude that there are approximately 100 billion stars in our galaxy alone with planets orbiting them.As we travel further into space, the entire galaxy becomes just a dot of light. Each of those other dots are other galaxies.Further away, it is possible to see the Virgo Supercluster. That red notation represents our local galactic group, containing all of the galaxies near us. In that is the Milky Way galaxy. In that is the solar interstellar neighborhood. In that is our solar system. In that is planet Earth.The local supercluster group contains the virgo supercluster, where we are located, as well as the other superclusters near us.That tiny dot that you can hardly make out on the screen is the Virgo Supercluster. All of those other dots are superclusters. And this is just the observable universe that we can estimate. It is believed that there are countless, perhaps even infinite, other dimensions. Theoretically, planet Earth could have entire civilizations that exist in other dimensions we can’t access or interact with at the present time. Then there is the issue of time and gravity. If time travel is possible, all of these universes would be occurring at the same time everywhere in all dimensions.Multiverse?The multiverse is a hypothetical group of multiple universes.Together, these universes comprise everything that exists: the entirety of space, time, matter, energy, information, and the physical laws and constants that describe them.Do you still think we are alone in the Universe?

question: https://www.quora.com/Do-you-need-advanced-technology-paired-with-curiosity-to-make-a-new-scientific-discovery-today-or-could-a-discovery-be-made-without-this-advanced-technology-and-just-curiosity

Answer: There have been many advances in all areas. Anesthesia is better- it is shorter acting and has less effect on suppressing the heart function. The heart lung machine works exactly the same but it is much more reliable. The drugs used to support the heart are hugely better. But maybe the biggest advance has been in understanding and controlling bleeding and the coagulation cascade. We can now determine exactly what blood products, such as platelets, cryoprecipitate, fresh frozen plasma, rbc’s, or the specific clotting factors that are needed. In addition, bioglue is a wonderful product. TogetherThere have been many advances in all areas. Anesthesia is better- it is shorter acting and has less effect on suppressing the heart function. The heart lung machine works exactly the same but it is much more reliable. The drugs used to support the heart are hugely better. But maybe the biggest advance has been in understanding and controlling bleeding and the coagulation cascade. We can now determine exactly what blood products, such as platelets, cryoprecipitate, fresh frozen plasma, rbc’s, or the specific clotting factors that are needed. In addition, bioglue is a wonderful product. Together, these advances help treat the number one complication of any surgery, which is bleeding.

question: https://www.quora.com/If-aliens-asked-you-to-go-away-with-them-without-knowing-anything-other-than-they-are-aliens-with-advanced-technology-would-you-go-and-why

Answer: I think there has been more progress on how to repair the heart as opposed to relying on transplants. Where possible, the emphasis is on minimally invasive techniques. Instead of cutting a 10-inch down the center of a patient's chest, devices are inserted via a large blood vessel in the chest or groin.The most recent of this type of treatment is TAVR, Transcather Aortic Valve Replacement. It is a way to replace the aortic valve, which is the valve that controls the flow of blood from the heart to the rest of the body.Other heart valves, such as mitral valves, can be repaired or replaced usingI think there has been more progress on how to repair the heart as opposed to relying on transplants. Where possible, the emphasis is on minimally invasive techniques. Instead of cutting a 10-inch down the center of a patient's chest, devices are inserted via a large blood vessel in the chest or groin.The most recent of this type of treatment is TAVR, Transcather Aortic Valve Replacement. It is a way to replace the aortic valve, which is the valve that controls the flow of blood from the heart to the rest of the body.Other heart valves, such as mitral valves, can be repaired or replaced using minimally invasive surgery, if the patient meets specific criteria.This approach speeds recovery and lowers the chance of infection. However, everyone is not a candidate for the procedure.I am a volunteer at a hospital that performs TAVRs and I have read about the procedure in the Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA. Patients can go to the JAMA website and sign up to receive newsletters on a variety of diseases and conditions for free.

Answer: Not a doctor. Responding to A2A.“After a heart is removed from a donor's body, it is placed in a high-tech OCS box and is immediately revived to a beating state, perfused with oxygen and nutrient-rich blood, and maintained at an appropriate temperature. The device also features monitors that display how the heart is functioning during transport.The current standard of transporting donor hearts in iceboxes in a non-functioning state, which has bNot a doctor. Responding to A2A.“After a heart is removed from a donor's body, it is placed in a high-tech OCS box and is immediately revived to a beating state, perfused with oxygen and nutrient-rich blood, and maintained at an appropriate temperature. The device also features monitors that display how the heart is functioning during transport.The current standard of transporting donor hearts in iceboxes in a non-functioning state, which has been used for decades, requires the restarting of the heart once it has been placed inside the recipient."The concept of transplanting a donor heart in a beating state is revolutionary," saidUCLA Heart and Vascular ServicesIn case that is “cheating” as it IS in clinical trials, then, again for TECH, would be inclined to go with the LVAD. Left Ventricular Assistive Devices allow for the recipient to hang in there longer so an appropriate donor heart can be obtained. There are, of course, issues with the LVAD, though some surgeons believe they may be able to replace transplants. (There are other things which are less “technological” that are important as well; ways to repair the heart are wonderful and are included in Drazner’s article above.

Answer: Dolphins and other Whales and related appear very intelligent and may have complex societies but they seem unable to produce and carry even primitive tools - flippers simply don’t make that practical. Otters are more likely to become technologically capable.Octopuses are also quite intelligent and have manipulative tentacles that they have been known to use simple tools with- but have so far failed to show any signs of sophisticated language or technology.
